image.altText: A woman wearing a black blazer stands with her hands in front of her

props.synopsis: Hayley Brown says she almost lost her life at the hands of a long-term partner. She is now one of the first victim-survivors to join a statewide lived experience advisory network.

title.children: Domestic violence survivor shares 'failures in the system' to spark change

image.altText: A woman stands behind the wheel of a yacht.

props.synopsis: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says it is providing consular assistance to the family of an Australian missing in the Mozambique Channel off the coast of Africa.

title.children: Family of Port Lincoln sailor fears she has died overseas

image.altText: An underwater shot in a water-filled cave, with rocks formations

props.synopsis: Police are investigating after a 65-year-old diver drowned at Tank Cave near Tantanoola in the state's south-east.

title.children: 65yo Victorian diver drowns at Tank Cave near Mount Gambier

image.altText: A man holds a trophy in one hand and smiles while wearing a yellow cap and black racing gear.

props.synopsis: Chaz Mostert breaks through for a maiden Supercars championship after rival Broc Feeney spins out on the opening lap at the Adelaide grand final.

title.children: Chaz Mostert wins maiden Supercars title in Adelaide

image.altText: Hundreds of flies gather on a feeding area.

props.synopsis: Researchers on Kangaroo Island have been breeding and releasing millions of sterile Australian sheep blowflies in an attempt to eradicate the pest.

title.children: Sterile flies take to the sky in Kangaroo Island eradication push

image.altText: A graphic including a newspaper front page, image of von Einem in sunglasses and an inset photo of victim Richard Kelvin

props.synopsis: One of South Australia's most notorious murderers was this week rushed to an infirmary on the brink of death, prompting recollections of the time when young males disappeared across Adelaide in a set of gruesome crimes dubbed "The Family" murders. Warning: This story contains details some readers may find distressing.

title.children: 'The Family' murders which stole Adelaide's innocence

image.altText: William Barratt 1880 first mormon

props.synopsis: It's been 185 years this month since Australia's first Mormon arrived in Adelaide. He immediately regretted the move.

title.children: Australia's first Mormon warned others of Adelaide's wickedness

image.altText: A blonde girl looking in the mirror as she films a video on her phone.

props.synopsis: Sex workers say viral social media content, which often promotes a life of luxury, needs to be more transparent to avoid duping young followers.

title.children: Young women say social media didn't prepare them for realities of sex work

image.altText: A collage of images including missing boy Gus Lamont.

props.synopsis: The disappearance of Gus Lamont is one of those events that have a seismic impact on public consciousness: they distress, disturb, upset and unsettle. This week six mine shafts were searched, providing no further clues in the case.

title.children: Gus has been gone for 63 days, and multiple searches have yielded no clues

image.altText: A middle aged woman with curly grey hair in a brown jacket in a tv studio

props.synopsis: The early childhood education minister is refusing to say whether the federal government will establish an independent review of childcare standards.

title.children: Minister will not commit to childcare inquiry despite safety concerns

image.altText: Two people outside a Bedford site.

props.synopsis: Former Bedford staff have said they are owed millions of dollars in entitlements after they were made redundant when the disability employment provider entered voluntary administration earlier this year.

title.children: Terminated Bedford staff in limbo, with millions owed in entitlements

image.altText: An 80-year-old woman looking straight into the camera.

props.synopsis: Decades on from Australia's forced adoption era, just two states have set up a redress scheme for the mothers who were harmed. Survivors are calling for South Australia to take similar action — warning time is running out.

title.children: Jo had her baby 'ripped away' at birth — she's one of thousands across Australia

image.altText: The Elizabeth City Centre shopping centre during a lockdown.

props.synopsis: A teenage boy is in hospital with life-threatening injuries after a stabbing at an Adelaide shopping centre in which a 20-year-old man was also injured.

title.children: Teens arrested over shopping centre stabbing that leaves two in hospital

image.altText: Young blonde girl in an outcrop of rocks.

props.synopsis: Renowned Australian director Peter Weir gives a rare behind-the-scenes insight into what made Picnic at Hanging Rock such a memorable and enduring film.

title.children: How Peter Weir captured a 'golden glow' in Picnic at Hanging Rock

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese with his wife, Jodie Haydon.

props.synopsis: It is hard to imagine a better end to the prime minister's year than this one, but realists in government know Labor can't continue to ride the wave.

title.children: Albanese and Labor are at their zenith. What a difference a year makes

image.altText: A newsreader with a digital mask over her face.

props.synopsis: With AI deepfakes causing confusion and harm online, the federal government tells tech developers that AI content should be clearly labelled, ahead of a National AI Plan due to be released.

title.children: Tech companies advised to label AI-generated content

image.altText: Headshot of Barnaby Joyce.

props.synopsis: Newly minted independent Barnaby Joyce says he'll make his decision on whether he'll defect to One Nation in the next couple of weeks. Follow live.

title.children: Joyce to make decision on move to One Nation in 'next couple of weeks'

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: A truncated session due to the Thanksgiving Day holiday in the US saw Wall Street post solid gains to close the month marginally higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street rises on limited trade and ASX set to inch higher

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Wall Street climbs on modest trading, ASX set to inch higher

image.altText: Salad harvester at work at sunrise.

props.synopsis: Australian salad grower Dicky Bill enters administration, putting 180 people out of work before Christmas.

title.children: Sudden shutdown of Australian salad grower puts 180 people out of work

image.altText: Tree trunks and debris covered in brown mud lie in front of a damaged house in an area hit by deadly flash floods.

props.synopsis: Torrential rain causes flash floods and landslides in Indonesia, where the toll rises as authorities mount rescue operations.

title.children: Rescue efforts underway after flash floods kill hundreds in Indonesia

image.altText: Sydney student accommodation Sharesorted 2025-11-28

props.synopsis: International students relying on education agents to study in Australia might be misled about the country's housing situation.

title.children: 'Unjust': International students trading their rights for a bed

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu gestures while addressing reporters from behind a lectern.

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has formally asked for a pardon from President Isaac Herzog relating to corruption charges against him.

title.children: Benjamin Netanyahu formally asks for pardon on corruption charges

image.altText: England cricket team walk out

props.synopsis: Australia's Ashes domination in Brisbane is almost total, with England winless at the Gabba since 1986. It wasn't always like this though, with the first visit to Brisbane resulting in the heaviest defeat in cricket history.

title.children: When England won an Ashes by 675 runs to crowd's 'horror and amazement'

props.synopsis: From reality TV and heist movie remakes to man's last step on the Moon — how well do you know this week in history?

title.children: The last man on the Moon: Can you ace this week's history quiz?

image.altText: An outline drawing of Pope Leo in front of a Lebanese cedar tree and a dove on a sign attached to metal barriers

props.synopsis: As Pope Leo visits Lebanon, many locals hope he will bring peace to the region, viewing the visit as a message of solidarity.

title.children: 'Big message of hope': Lebanese welcome Pope Leo as peacemaker

image.altText: Travis Head raises his bat as he leaves the field in the first Ashes Test in Perth.

props.synopsis: Travis Head says he has no qualms if he is shifted back down Australia's batting order following his exploits as an opener in the first Ashes Test.

title.children: Head happy to 'play any role' in day-night Ashes Test

image.altText: Explosions light the night sky orange during a huge fire

props.synopsis: The inferno-like fire broke out at Kurrajong Street in North St Mary’s overnight, generating immense heat and a huge eruption that spewed a fireball more than 100 metres up into the sky.

title.children: Firies fighting Sydney blaze 'had never seen an explosion fire so big'

image.altText: A bushfire burning close to homes.

props.synopsis: Firefighters defended properties in the outer Geraldton suburbs of Waggrakine and Moresby as a bushfire burned close to homes on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: Homes threatened by Geraldton suburbs bushfire with challenging conditions today

image.altText: Two men in the pub, one is Wayde Chiesa, one is David Crisafulli

props.synopsis: A week is a long time in politics, let alone three years, and the LNP's success at the next election is by no means assured, writes Jack McKay.

title.children: Hinchinbrook by-election result no crystal ball for LNP government's future

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese with his wife, Jodie Haydon.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and Jodie Haydon will head off on a five-day honeymoon on Monday after an intimate wedding at The Lodge among only their closest family and friends.

title.children: Albanese and Haydon to head off on honeymoon after surprise wedding

image.altText: Sunrise on beach

props.synopsis: After a soaking November, this week could deliver a very brief reprieve from the storms and scorching heat.

title.children: Queensland to enjoy cooler, drier first days of summer — but not for long

image.altText: Two people are suspended on the side of a large coal ship holding a banner which reads "phase out coal and gas".

props.synopsis: Police arrest 141 people in Newcastle Harbour for alleged marine-related offences during an anti-fossil fuel protest that began on Thursday.

title.children: Protesters arrested for blocking world's largest coal export port

image.altText: A backyard with childrens' toys flooded

props.synopsis: Runoff from heavy rainfall and poor drainage can cause damage to properties and worsen flooding. So, who's responsible if your property experiences runoff, and what can you do about it?

title.children: Who's responsible when stormwater flows onto your property?

image.altText: a crashed light plane aircraft in the bushes after a mid air collision in wedderburn

props.synopsis: Emergency services were called to Napper Field, in Wedderburn about 11:50am on Sunday following reports of a crash.

title.children: Pilot dead after light aircraft collide mid-air
